awd_titl_txt: US Ignite: Collaborative Research: Focus Area 2: Rethinking Home Networking for the Ultrabroadband Era
awd_abstract_narration:
With the capacity ultra-broadband residential networks provide we have the opportunity to re-center our digital lives around our residence.  This re-structuring offers societal-scale benefits. Rather than spreading our digital lives across myriad services and providers across the Internet, we will enable individuals to retain control of their resources while at the same time sharing them with friends and trusted services, as needed and on demand. The advent of ultrabroadband residential networks facilitates this change, as individuals will now have the resources to serve their own data in a way they see fit, rather than being beholden to large service providers for the required resources.

This project develops the technology to fruitfully leverage the raw capacity of ultra-broadband residential networks to shift a residential user's digital hub to his or her residence. The project focuses on two themes. The first theme is centered around an appliance in homes -- a home point of presence -- that provides a variety of services to the users in the house regardless of where they are physically located and hence connected to the network. A base-level service is a 'data attic', or a single place for users to store all their information that leaves them in direct control over the use of their data. We introduce infrastructureless Content Distribution Networks that aim to leverage homes with ultra-broadband connectivity to move us away from delivering content from large service providers and towards massively distributed delivery that is ultimately cheaper and faster. Our second theme involves monitoring the operational Case Connection Zone ultra-broadband fiber-to-the-home network to better understand how protocols and applications can be extended to work better in such high-speed residential settings.

por.por_cntn:
Intellectual Merit:

This project posed a general question: How can we re-think the organization of networks, applications and data to capitalize on the new opportunities provided by ultrabroadband networks?  To address this question, we proposed, prototyped and investigated several services that would be enabled by ultra-broadband, all facilitated by a new home-based network appliance we proposed and called ?Home Point of Presence?, or HPoP. These services included NoCDN, a "gig economy" alternative to traditional content delivery networks that allows users to sell their excess bandwidth and HPoP?s computing capacity to content providers to scale up the delivery of providers' content -- while providing verifiable content integrity and honest billing; DCol, which allows users to form a collective, with their HPoPs forming overlay networks to route communication around Internet hot spots and otherwise trouble areas; and a Data Attic, the system that allows users to take control over the data that various providers, such as health care providers, generate about the users.  Thus, besides proposing new beneficial services, another significant project outcome is that it proved by construction that ultrabroadband opens up opportunities for new richer services, and thus it offers qualitative benefits that extend beyond purely speeding up existing applications.

The project also conducted Internet measurements to understand various aspects of the Internet that would be affected by the wide adoption of ultrabroadband at home. In particular, we focused on Domain Name System (DNS), a key Internet component that maps human-readable names, such as ?cnn.com? to Internet addresses of the hosts that provide the corresponding content. We investigated support and usage of some important features of the DNS protocol and uncovered important gaps and pitfalls that can negate intended benefits of these features, unnecessarily expose client information, or even disrupt Internet access in some situations.  These outcomes are already having an impact on the operational community.

Yet another outcome is a new design and implementation of traceroute, which is optimized for massive-scale measurements.  Traceroute is a tool for discovering the sequence of routers connecting the vantage point to a specified target host, and it is a fundamental utility for Internet exploration and trouble-shooting.  Our implementation, which we named FlashRoute, is able to traceroute every routable /24 subnet (the smallest subnet granularity that the Internet-wide routing protocol supports) over three times faster than the previous state-of-the art while discovering the same number of router interfaces.

Broader Impacts:

The novel services explored in the project have a potential to impact regular Internet users. At the same time, by providing examples of substantive functional benefits of ultrabroadband, the project adds further motivation for ultrabroadband to the homes (beyond simply speeding up existing applications) and informs the discussion regarding about Internet investment priorities in the society at large.

Our DNS measurements, especially the pitfalls they uncovered, have already impacted the practice among some operators of DNS resolution services and content delivery networks, according to anecdotal evidence from blog posts and personal communication we received.  And FlashRoute, which we only recently made publicly available, is already spawning follow-up development by others, with five forks seen by our FlashRoute repository at github.

In terms of education and training, the project helped to train three PhD students, five MS students, and five undergraduates. It also had substantial impact on two courses taught by the PI: the undergraduate course "Computer Networks 1", where it facilitated discussions on Internet architecture principles, the organization of home and access networks, and the security and privacy issues, and on the graduate course "Internet Security and privacy", where we used topics derived from this research to add a module on CDN security. The project also introduced 5 undergraduate students to networking research through the REU supplement and endowed them with critical skills in low-level network programming and network measurement data analysis.
